div.l: What shul we speken alday of holy writte
The deuel made a Reve forto preche
Or of a Souter a Shipman or a leche
Sey furth thy tale mysspend not thy time
Lo depford and it is half wey prime
Lo grenewich ther many a shrew is in
It were al time this tale to begynne
Now sirs coth this Oswold the Reue
I pray you alle that ye not greve
This drunken Milner hath y told us her͗e
Hough that begilid was a carpinter͗e
ꝐParauenture in scorn̄ for I am one
And by youre leue I shal him quite anon̄
Right in his charlis termes wille I speke
I pray to god his necke mot he breke
He can wel in myn̄ eye se a stalke
But in his owne he can not se a balke
Here begynneth the Revis tale
AT Trūmpingtoıı̄un not ferre from Cambrigge
Ther goth a broke and oủer that a brigge
Vpon the which broke ther stant a Mille
And this is veray soth that I you telle
A Milner was ther duelling many a day
As any pecoc he was stout and gay
Pipe he couth and fissh and nettis bete
And turne cuppis and wel couth wrastle ⁊and shete
Ay by his belt he bare a long panade
And of a Swerd ful trenchant was the blade
A ioly popper bare he in his pouche
Ther nas noman for peril durst him touch
A Sheffeld twitle bare he in his hose
Rounde was his face ⁊and camusid was his nose
And pillid as an ape was his sculle
He was a market beter atte the fulle
Ther durst no wight hand upon̄ him legge
That he ne swore anone he shuld abegge
A theef he was forsoth of corn̄ ⁊and mele
And that a sligh and usant forto stele
His name was hoten deynous Symkyn̄
A wif he had comen̄ of noble kynne
The parson̄ of the toun̄ hir fadir was
With hir he yave many a panne a bras
For that Symkyn̄ shuld in his blood allye
